title: Facebook Needs Users to Shop, Not Drop
summary: As user engagement wanes in key areas, the social-media company is hustling to bolster direct shopping channels to maintain its edge. Facebook is still riding a pandemic high, with ads successfully driving impulse purchases of everything its users didn't even know they wanted. But longer term it will need to become more of a destination for users to buy exactly what they know they need.

title: Apple Couldn't Dodge Chip Pain Forever
summary: Sales surged in the March quarter, but the iPhone maker warned constraints would be felt in June period. For a company that generates more than 80% of its revenue selling gadgets packed with chips, Apple sure has managed to sell a lot of them.

title: Private Equity and Hedge Funds, Facing a New Tax Burden, Prepare Their Defense
summary: Wall Street firms that benefit from carried-interest treatment say Biden's proposal could discourage small-business investment. Some private-equity firms and hedge funds are pushing back against a proposal from President Biden to end the carried-interest tax advantage these types of firms enjoy.

title: Three Men in Ahmaud Arbery Killing Charged With Federal Hate Crimes
summary: Black jogger's shooting death in Georgia in 2020 sparked outcry; three white defendants have pleaded not guilty to state murder charges. Three men have been indicted on federal hate crimes charges in the killing of Ahmaud Arbery, a 25-year-old Black man who was chased and fatally shot in February 2020 while out jogging in southeast Georgia, the Justice Department said Wednesday.

title: Biden's Cradle-to-Grave Government
summary: His latest $1.8 trillion plan rejects the old social contract of work for benefits.. The progressive hits keep coming from the Biden Administration, and the latest is the $1.8 trillion American Families Plan introduced in broad strokes on Wednesday. It's more accurate to call this the plan to make the middle class dependent on government from cradle to grave. The government will tell you sometime later, after you're hooked to the state, how it will force you to pay for it.

title: Two Sigma Impact and Avance Back Artisan Supplier
summary: The investment in Wholesale Supplies Plus marks an exit for Incline Equity Partners, which invested in the e-commerce company in 2019. Two Sigma Impact, the impact strategy of investment manager Two Sigma Investments, is backing Wholesale Supplies Plus LLC, an e-commerce provider of ingredients and materials to commercial artisans.

title: Facebook's Ad Business Drives Surge in Revenue
summary: Social-media company says it expects its growth to slow in second half of year as pandemic lift fades and Apple's limits on ad tracking roll out. Facebook Inc.'s booming advertising business drove revenue and profit sharply higher, as the company pledged to navigate Apple Inc.'s new ad-targeting rules and accelerate investments in e-commerce, mixed reality and tools to help creators make money from their content.

title: The Latest Earmark Excuse
summary: They won't help Congress debate spending honestly.. Politicians have invented some creative justifications for spending earmarks over the years, but give Vermont Democrat Pat Leahy extra credit. The Senate Appropriations Chairman wants America to think a return to pork-barrel spending will solve Congress's budgeting dysfunction.

title: No Escape From Hong Kong
summary: New legislation lets the government block people from leaving.. Mark another step in Hong Kong's descent: On Wednesday the Legislative Council made it easier for the government to block Hong Kongers from leaving.

title: Pipeline Dispute Draws Competing Concerns from Supreme Court
summary: Justices consider whether pipeline developer can use federal power to seize state land. WASHINGTON-The U.S. government in 2018 approved a new natural gas pipeline in the Northeast and gave the developer federal eminent domain power to acquire the land to build it. New Jersey objected when the builder then moved to take state property. What happens now?

title: Beefless Journalism
summary: To address climate change, Epicurious deserts beef recipes.. Beef is off the menu at Condé Nast. The editors of its food publication Epicurious announced Monday they would no longer publish recipes, articles, social media, or newsletters featuring beef.

title: Ford Posts Highest Quarterly Net Income in Years
summary: Auto maker's bottom line reversed a $2 billion loss from a year earlier. Ford Motor Co. posted $3.3 billion in net income-its highest quarterly result in years-but warned the financial toll from the continuing global computer-chip shortage will likely worsen.

title: The Music City Meltdown
summary: A decade ago Nashville's rise seemed inevitable, but fiscal recklessness left the city ill-prepared to absorb the pandemic's economic blows.. For more than a decade, Nashville, Tenn., has been one of America's hippest and fastest-growing cities. Anchored by the country-music industry and boosted by a hospitable state tax climate, the city and surrounding region attracted businesses and residents. While its music scene made it a tourist mecca, Nashville also lured a generation of college-educated transplants, earning a position as one of the country's new "brainpower cities."

title: Your Woke Money Is No Good Here
summary: Corporations have taken advantage of Republicans for too long. I won't take their PAC dollars anymore.. Georgia's new election law runs 98 generously spaced pages. A fast reader can get through it in one sitting. If you're the CEO of a major corporation, you can pay someone to do it for you. But I don't think CEOs took the time to read Georgia's Election Integrity Act of 2021, because so much of what they said about it was nonsense.

title: Lockdowns Give School Choice a Boost
summary: Under Biden, advocates expected a setback. But the movement has notched notable victories this year.. President Biden wants credit for opening up the nation's schools within 100 days of taking office. Yet over a third of U.S. students still aren't going to a classroom every day. Many urban districts open their doors only to young children or for just two days a week, and scare talk dissuades numerous parents from sending their kids.

title: Government Won't Fix the Semiconductor Shortage
summary: The semiconductor and auto industries will resolve the issue before politicians finish assigning blame.. Jerry Sanders, a former chairman of the Semiconductor Industry Association and a founder of Advanced Micro Devices , predicted in the 1970s that "semiconductors would prove to be the crude oil of the information age." It was an understatement.

title: A New Coalition to Advance U.S. Global Interests
summary: We hope to unite people who disagreed on Trump behind six principles of American foreign policy.. The U.S. is at a critical crossroads when it comes to the defense of American freedom, security and prosperity. Around the world, the U.S. faces significant national-security threats. Chief among them are revisionist powers, the spread of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, and transnational terrorism and crime-all made more dangerous by renewed great-power competition with, and myriad threats posed by, the Chinese Communist Party.

title: Fed Holds Steady on Rates, Notes Recent Economic Gains
summary: Central bank maintains easy-money policies while noting recent economic gains. WASHINGTON-The Federal Reserve held its key interest rate near zero and said it plans to continue supporting the economic recovery, while acknowledging recent progress in growth and employment.

title: Joe Biden's Art of the Non-Deal
summary: Negotiating with the opposition, the left concluded, merely impedes achieving their policy goals.. At 100 days, 90% of Joe Biden's presidency can be summed up in one sentence: Whatever Donald Trump did, do the opposite.

title: 'Peace, Poverty and Betrayal' Review: To Oblige and Rule
summary: Britain's connection to India shaped the views of political philosophers and goaded the British into major reforms, at home and abroad.. As India reels from the Covid pandemic, is it wrong to ask whether independent India is really taking better care of Indians than the British Raj did? This question-yes, provocative-isn't one that Roderick Matthews poses in "Peace, Poverty and Betrayal," a book he describes as "a new history of British India." But many of his readers could be tempted to ask it as they observe present-day Indians die in the thousands from a lack of hospital beds, medicines and oxygen-dying, in fact, from the sort of callous and conspicuous dereliction of care that we've been schooled to ascribe to colonial rulers.

title: Biden Proposal Would Close Real-Estate Tax Loophole
summary: President's economic plan would end deferred capital-gains payments on property sales. President Biden's new economic plan would eliminate a tax break for many real-estate owners that has enabled them to defer paying capital gains on property sales.

title: New York to End Curfew on Restaurants, Bars
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo says he is easing Covid-19 restrictions because state has made enough progress in fighting virus. ALBANY, N. Y.-The curfew on New York's bars and restaurants will be lifted next month, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Wednesday, as state lawmakers repealed a mandate that food be served to everyone who buys an alcoholic drink.

title: Florida GOP Lawmakers Advance Voting-Law Changes
summary: Legislation including new rules on drop boxes and voter identification heads back to the Senate. Florida's Republican-controlled legislature advanced a measure that would tighten vote-by-mail rules, marking the latest state-level push to change election rules after voters flocked to remote voting during the pandemic.

title: 'Things Heard & Seen' Review: The Horror of the Unknown
summary: In a smart Netflix film based on the book 'All Things Cease to Appear,' Amanda Seyfried stars as a young mother who comes to suspect that her marriage and new home have a dark side. It's the rare supernatural thriller that finds its philosophical underpinnings in the Christian mystic Emanuel Swedenborg (1688-1772), who was viewed as both enlightened and mad but can certainly put a spin on a ghost story: Per Swedenborg's benign view of the spirit world, it isn't the dead of "Things Heard & Seen" who should inspire loathing. It's the living.

title: Senate Votes to Reverse Trump-Era Loosening of Methane Emission Rules
summary: Lawmakers backed restoring regulations for emissions that leak into the air from oil and gas production. The Senate voted to restore regulations on methane gas that leaks into the air from U.S. oil and gas production, reversing a Trump-era policy and giving a boost to the Biden administration's goal of reducing emissions.

title: Verizon Explores Sale of Media Assets
summary: Private-equity firms including Apollo are among possible bidders for Verizon media assets, sources say. Verizon Communications Inc. is exploring a sale of assets including Yahoo and AOL, as the telecommunications giant looks to exit an expensive and unsuccessful bet on digital media.

title: France's Macron Eyes Artificial Intelligence to Monitor Terrorism
summary: The move comes as the French president comes under pressure to crack down on terrorism and Islamist separatism. PARIS-The government of French President Emmanuel Macron aims to deploy algorithms and other technology to monitor the web-browsing of terror suspects amid growing tensions over a group of retired generals who recently warned the country was sliding toward a civil war.

title: Supreme Court Weighs Limits to Schools' Power to Patrol Student Speech
summary: Angry cheerleader's intemperate Snapchat drew a yearlong suspension from team that Pennsylvania school board asks court to reinstate. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court signaled reluctance Wednesday to extend throughout the internet campus rules that curb student speech, as arguments drew wide agreement among justices that the First Amendment lets public schools address threats and cyberbullying but not punish expression merely because administrators find it distasteful.

title: Oregon Reverses Some Reopenings as Covid-19 Cases, Hospitalizations Jump
summary: Weekly cases have increased more than 20% in the past five weeks. Oregon is placing a large portion of the state under new restrictions, pulling back on recent reopenings as Covid-19 cases and hospitalizations climb once more.

title: Video of Police Killing of Anthony Alvarez Released by Chicago Officials
summary: City officials say they are reworking city's foot-pursuit policy after death of 22-year-old man. CHICAGO-Chicago officials on Wednesday released video footage of a police officer shooting and killing 22-year-old Anthony Alvarez after a foot chase, the second such release this month.

title: What Does Biden's Plan for Families Mean for Community College, Pre-K?
summary: The $1.8 trillion plan would offer students four more years of free schooling. On Wednesday, in advance of his address before Congress, President Biden unveiled his $1.8 trillion "American Families Plan." The administration is proposing offering four more years of free schooling for all students: two in the form of universal prekindergarten for 3- and 4-year-olds and two after high school in the form of tuition-free community college.

title: Why Is Coeur d'Alene America's Hottest Housing Market?
summary: The Wall Street Journal/Realtor.com Emerging Housing Market Index identifies the top metro areas for home buyers.. The lakeside city of Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, tops the list of the country's hottest emerging housing markets, according to the ranking. The Wall Street Journal/Realtor.com Emerging Housing Market Index ranks the 300 biggest metro areas in the U.S. The rankings look at which housing markets are expected to provide a strong return on investment-and are a nice place to live. After Coeur d'Alene, the top metro areas in the ranking are Austin, Texas, Springfield, Ohio, and Billings, Mont. Spokane, Wash., just across the state border from Coeur d'Alene, ranks fifth.

title: After a Viral Love Song, Girl in Red Debuts Her New Album
summary: The Norwegian alternative artist is part of a new wave of pop musicians who are bringing a rawer, more intimate sound that centers introspection and emotional honesty. Girl in Red, the Norwegian alternative musician whose debut album arrives on Friday, is drawing a growing Gen Z audience thanks to her yearning songs about infatuation, heartbreak and mental health.

title: Video of Andrew Brown Shooting to Be Released Publicly in 30-Plus Days
summary: North Carolina judge denies request to release body-cam and dashboard footage immediately. A North Carolina judge said video footage of the fatal police shooting of Andrew Brown Jr. would be kept from public view for at least a month but that Mr. Brown's family members could watch the videos privately much sooner.

title: Biden's Tax Plan Expands Federal Grants, but Doesn't Include Student Loan Forgiveness
summary: The $1.8 trillion dollar plan includes provisions aimed at reducing the amount of student debt taken on by students in the future. President Biden's American Families Plan was released on Wednesday with a number of proposed provisions that would lessen the amount of student debt taken on by future students.

title: D.C. Statehood Needs a Constitutional Fix
summary: To make D.C. a state or to continue it as a district while granting full congressional representation, or its retrocession to Maryland, can be only accomplished by constitutional amendment.. Regarding your editorial "The D.C. Statehood Gambit" (April 22): The Constitution's Article 1, Section 8, provides for the possibility of "such District (not exceeding ten Miles square) as may, by Cession of particular States." At the 1788 New York ratifying convention Alexander Hamilton proposed a constitutional amendment to remedy the proposed district's lack of representation if an unspecified population threshold was realized. It was not agreed to. In 1846 the Virginia portion of the cession was ceded back to it, indicating that the District of Columbia as a geographical entity (within the limit of 100 square miles) was malleable.

title: Biden's Climate Plan Is Wise and Necessary
summary: The U.S. is competing with China and other countries for leadership on both climate protection and the industries and the jobs of the future. We must win this race.. Your April 23 editorial "Biden's 10-Year Climate Plan" gets one thing right: Cleaning up the power grid and electrifying transportation and buildings are needed to meet the president's target of cutting U.S. climate pollution in half by 2030 and reaching net-zero emissions by 2050.

title: Election Objectors Brought Disaster to GOP
summary: The Republicans who voted to decertify the last presidential election and haven't publicly asked for forgiveness of their sins against our democracy will receive no support from me.. After the despicable events of Jan. 6, I have taken time to reflect upon whom I shall continue to support in the House of Representatives ("PACs Cut Funds to Election Objectors," U.S. News, April 17). The Republicans who voted to decertify the last presidential election and haven't publicly asked for forgiveness of their sins against our democracy will receive no support from me. They are delusional transgressors against our Constitution and an anathema to our Founding Fathers.

title: The Supreme Court Is Not Meant to Be Apportioned
summary: The role of the courts, including the Supreme Court, is to objectively and without bias decide cases based on what the law says.. An April 23 letter from Ian Silverman regarding term limits for the Supreme Court reveals an increasingly common misconception about the nature of the court. Mr. Silverman states that: "Term limits would provide a greater assurance that presidents of both parties will appoint our justices, helping the higher court reflect the will of the people." The role of the courts, including the Supreme Court, is to objectively and without bias decide cases based on what the law says. This may or may not be what the will of the people currently is. The "will of the people" is subject to change, and should not be the basis for judicial decisions.

title: Gottlieb Is Right About Wearing Masks Outdoors
summary: If this year has taught me anything, it is that people are egregiously prone to be obedient to baseless government pronouncements.. Thanks to Dr. Scott Gottlieb for pointing out the absurdity of wearing masks outdoors to prevent Covid-19 transmission ("Time to End Outdoor Mask Edicts," op-ed, April 26). I am old enough to collect Social Security and love walking outdoors with my wife every chance we get. We live near the ocean where there is usually a fresh, stiff breeze blowing, and often a gale. Nevertheless, as we traverse our well-worn beaches and trails, we encounter many people wearing masks, and parents often have their young children wearing them as well. If this year has taught me anything, it is that people are egregiously prone to be obedient to baseless government pronouncements echoed by many in a mindless and obedient media. That is one of the saddest outcomes of this pandemic.

title: Stocks Slip After Fed Holds Rates Steady
summary: Indexes hover near records as the corporate earnings season gets off to better-than-expected start. U.S. stocks ticked lower Wednesday after the Federal Reserve said it would stick to the loose monetary policy that has underpinned the market's rally in recent months.

title: Airbus Subsidiary Pleads Guilty in Saudi Bribery Case

title: New York City Mayoral Candidate Scott Stringer Accused of Sexual Harassment

summary: Five states including Uttar Pradesh account for about 35% of the country's active coronavirus cases. title: 5 Summer Skirts Almost as Good as an Italian Vacation
summary: Can't travel to the Amalfi Coast for a sunny holiday? No problem. These breezy cotton styles will help transport you to the seaside-no matter how landlocked your summer digs may be.. EVEN IF YOU'RE not lavishly vacationing on the Amalfi Coast, you can dress like you are. Though the closest most of us will get to Italy this summer is imagining we're Gwyneth Paltrow pining for Jude Law in the midcentury "Mongibello" milieu of 1999's "The Talented Mr. Ripley," or Audrey Hepburn evading her royal duties on the back of a Vespa in 1953's "Roman Holiday," clothes can prove transporting. Classic 1950s cotton skirts in colorful prints are an easy way to channel sunnier and more romantic locales.

title: The IRS Is Biden's Infrastructure
summary: Funding massive entitlements with payers to be named later.. President Joe Biden will focus his Wednesday night speech on one of his multitrillion-dollar spending plans. This one aims to make permanent many of the enacted and proposed emergency entitlements of 2020, especially in education. Ironically, this sector of the economy has experienced a windfall of federal subsidies over the past year even while many practitioners have remained far away from classrooms. But while teachers unions may be controversial, they are not nearly as unpopular as tax collectors, who also figure prominently in tonight's presentation. The new Biden plan relies on an historic expansion of Washington's most infamous bully, the Internal Revenue Service.

title: The Crushing Burden of Healthcare Microregulation
summary: To improve patient care, doctors need freedom from the intrusive rules set by insurers, medical societies and government agencies.. When my wife finally made the decision to close her medical practice, she said it was because of the endless paperwork that often left her in tears by the end of the day. Trying to get "prior authorization" from insurers for medications she prescribed, for example, consumed hours of practice time and sometimes resulted in weeks of treatment delays. "I don't see how I can keep this up," she'd been saying for years.

WASHINGTON-Security measures have been heightened at the Capitol ahead of President Biden's first address to Congress on Wednesday because of Covid-19 and lingering safety concerns months after pro-Trump rioters stormed the complex on Jan. 6.

title: IPG, WPP Report Return to Organic Revenue Growth
summary: The agency holding companies follow rivals Omnicom and Publicis in reporting signs of recovery after the impact of the pandemic. Interpublic Group of Cos. and WPP PLC both reported a return to organic revenue growth in the first quarter of 2021, adding to signs the advertising industry is turning a corner after a year of uncertainty stemming from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Want a Peek at Post-Covid Life? Check Out Gibraltar
summary: Resume Subscription. GIBRALTAR-On this strip of densely populated rock jutting into the Mediterranean Sea, people are tasting freedom.

title: In Ukraine's East, Fears Grow of New Russian Power Play
summary: Resume Subscription. AVDIIVKA, Ukraine-Arthur Volodymyrovych ducked his head down as he walked along the bottom of a trench last week, hoping to avoid sniper fire from Russia-backed separatists positioned less than 900 feet away.

title: Can't Decide What to Stream? Netflix's New Feature Will Choose for You
summary: Streaming service says 'Play Something' button will starts playing a television show or movie without making you pick. Netflix Inc. has rolled out a feature designed to alleviate a very modern malady: the so-called choice fatigue experienced when deciding what to watch next on a streaming service. Its solution is a "Play Something" button that, as its name suggests, starts playing a television show or movie without making you pick.

title: Microsoft Can No Longer Fly Under the Radar
summary: A $2 trillion market value raises the stakes for software giant's performance and could bring additional scrutiny. As Microsoft is learning early, $2 trillion comes with a price.

title: Vaccines Appear to Be Slowing Spread of Covid-19 Infections
summary: With more than 37% of U.S. adults fully vaccinated, Anthony Fauci expects case numbers to drop significantly. Vaccines appear to be starting to curb new Covid-19 infections in the U.S., a breakthrough that could help people return to more normal activities as infection worries fade, public-health officials say.

title: Alphabet, Pinterest, Mondelez, Dogecoin: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Results are due from Apple and Facebook. Here's what we're watching ahead of Wednesday's opening bell.

title: MessageBird Investors Inject $1 Billion to Help Finance U.S. Expansion
summary: The communications technology provider is using fresh capital to acquire private-equity-backed SparkPost. MessageBird BV has received roughly $1 billion in private-equity investments that the Amsterdam-based communications technology company is using to bolster its U.S. market share and its product offerings.

title: Books to Read: The Best Reviews of April
summary: 'The Agitators,' 'The Man Who Lived Underground' and more of the books our reviewers singled out for praise..

title: The U.S. Cities Where Airlines See the Most Growth
summary: Austin, Boston and Raleigh-Durham are among the mini-hubs the major carriers will be fighting over this year, to the benefit of air passengers. Is your city about to get the gift of more direct flights?

title: Credit Suisse, Bank of America, Credit Agricole Fined by EU for Bond-Trading Cartel
summary: Three banks fined a combined total of $34.4 million. Deutsche Bank avoided a penalty by informing the EU about the cartel.. The European Union fined Credit Suisse Group AG , Bank of America Corp. and Crédit Agricole SA for illegally colluding on trades in government bond markets at the expense of their clients.

title: Supermodel Amber Valletta on the One Achievement She's Most Proud of
summary: The WSJ. cover star shares the secrets to her success. What's the one piece of advice that you live by?

title: Hiroshi Sugimoto's Radical Traditionalism
summary: The Japanese photographer and architect, who's redesigning the Hirshhorn Museum's sculpture garden, is tired of modern architecture and much of the art made amid contemporary capitalism. Hiroshi Sugimoto has dedicated much of his art to capturing the fleeting sense of time. He photographs buildings with ultralong exposures, lending them a blurred effect, as though they were dissolving with the passage of history. His grainy seascape photographs, their blocky waviness like black-and-white Rothkos, feel boundless, as though one might fall into them. As an architect, the buildings he designs with centuries-old techniques also seem to be a part of that infinite past.

title: The Granddaughter Revitalizing Her 94-Year-Old Grandmother's French Design Glory
summary: Odile Mir created thrilling designs for the brand Prisunic in the late '60s and into the '70s. Now her granddaughter, interior designer Léonie Alma Mason, is bringing them back.. In the late 1960s, the French sculptor Odile Mir was hired as a freelance designer at the Delmas lighting factory, in Montauban, in the southern French region of Occitanie-an hour's drive from Saint-Sulpice-la-Pointe, the village where she lived with her husband and teenage daughter. She was the only female designer working in the factory, conceiving and producing lighting prototypes to be sold to major department stores all over France. (She had already learned welding from the blacksmith in her town.) At night, she stayed back after everyone had gone home and focused on her "real work" as an established artist, which saw her creating imposing bronze and steel sculptural forms and figures that towered above her 5-foot-3-inch frame.

title: Gavin Newsom Recall: What Happens Next?
summary: California governor almost certain to face recall election later this year, the sixth attempt by Republican activists since he was elected. California Gov. Gavin Newsom is almost certain to face a recall election in the fall of 2021 after California's secretary of state confirmed on April 26 that election officials have verified 1.63 million signatures on a recall petition. Just under 1.5 million verified signatures were needed.

title: Deutsche Bank Is Drama-Free for Now
summary: Sidestepping the Archegos debacle reinforces the lender's turnaround story. Investors may soon start asking what comes next.. After years of drama, Deutsche Bank has become boring. That is welcome, but also brings closer the moment when the lender will be judged on something wider-and in some ways harder to resolve-than a corporate overhaul.

title: More Companies Buy Back Shares, Pay Dividends a Year Into Pandemic
summary: U.S. businesses, many of them no longer facing cash-flow woes, are returning more capital to shareholders. Companies are spending more money on dividends and share repurchases after pausing or shrinking them last spring in an effort to preserve cash during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Trevor Lawrence Has Always Been No. 1
summary: The Clemson quarterback was the top college recruit in America. He won a championship. Now he'll finally be the top pick in the draft.. Two years ago, Clemson browbeat Alabama 44-16 in the national championship. It was the most lopsided loss of Nick Saban's tenure in Tuscaloosa. And every day since that blowout in January 2019, the first pick of the NFL draft in April 2021 has been a certainty: Trevor Lawrence, the quarterback who wrecked the greatest college football coach ever and made it look easy at age 19.

title: Sony Eyes a Broader Entertainment Empire
summary: Electronics-and-entertainment company is betting on broader content offerings as pandemic's boost fades. The pandemic's boost is fading for Sony , but the company's longer term content-focused strategy still looks likely to pay off.

title: When the EU's Covid-19 Vaccine Drive Stumbled, It Turned to Mr. Fixit
summary: Thierry Breton, a seasoned French executive, tracked vaccine supplies, pressured pharma companies to deliver. 'We will win this fight.'. Thierry Breton knew the European Union's vaccine campaign needed help when his boss called him in January.

title: Venture Firms Bask in a Surge of Blockbuster Profits
summary: Sutter Hill's Snowflake bet eclipses some of the biggest returns in U.S. startup history. Nearly a decade ago, venture-capital firm Sutter Hill Ventures made a small wager on an idea for a cloud computing services company, helping found and fund Snowflake Inc.

title: 7-Eleven Taps 'Spring Breakers' Director Harmony Korine for $70 Million Marketing Campaign
summary: Convenience chain works to keep consumers coming amid increasingly convenient e-commerce. 7-Eleven Inc. is rolling out its biggest television advertising push in years as part of a marketing campaign to counter increasing competition from all sides and to gain a new look from shoppers.

title: OpenAP Launches Data Tool Meant to Streamline TV Ad Buying
summary: The industry group's system creates an identifier that ultimately will let advertisers measure reach across both digital and traditional TV networks. TV ad industry consortium OpenAP is launching a so-called identifier to help advertisers more efficiently place and measure ads across separate digital and traditional TV systems.

title: ATL Partners-Led Group Invests in Arrive Logistics
summary: The group became the largest investor in the freight-brokerage company, while early backer Lead Edge Capital sold a portion of its stake. ATL Partners led a group backing a $300 million-plus investment in Arrive Logistics, giving the group the largest stake in the freight-brokerage company.

title: Fidelity Launches Platform for Fund Managers to Profit From Short Sellers
summary: Boston firm launched securities-lending business in-house two years ago and is now extending those services to other asset managers. Fidelity Investments Inc. is ramping up a business that helps money managers profit on those eager to bet against stocks.

title: Huawei's Sales Drop Steepens Under Weight of U.S. Sanctions
summary: Chinese tech giant suffers second straight quarterly drop in revenue as smartphone sales drop. HONG KONG-Huawei Technologies Co. reported a steepening decline in revenue in the first quarter, as its smartphone sales tumbled and the Chinese tech giant continued to struggle under U.S. sanctions.

title: Deutsche Bank Avoids Archegos Meltdown, Reports Profit Surge
summary: Bank benefits from frenzied investor activity in a volatile market and companies raising funding and merging. Deutsche Bank AG reported its strongest quarter in seven years thanks to activity at its investment bank, while the lender escaped the implosion of Archegos Capital Management that badly hit some rivals.

title: At-Home Covid-19 Tests Might Cost Too Much for Regular Use
summary: Rapid, paper-strip tests are arriving at pharmacies with price tags of $20 or more for two tests. Covid-19 tests for people to use to get quick results at home are finally becoming available to buy at pharmacies and retailers. Yet an obstacle might stand in the way of regular use: cost.

title: Ohio Town Grapples With Tearing Down Cold War Plant
summary: Resume Subscription. PIKETON, Ohio-Through the trees around her home, Elizabeth Lamerson can see part of the 70-year-old uranium-enrichment plant that government contractors plan to start tearing down this week. In this small Appalachian community, she and many of her neighbors say they are worried about any escape of radioactive material and the impact it could have on their health.

title: Saudi Arabia to Sell More Aramco Stakes
summary: After its 2019 IPO failed to generate much foreign demand, Aramco is in talks to sell a 1% stake to an unnamed global energy company. Saudi Arabia is talking with unnamed foreign investors about selling stakes in Aramco, with options that include a 1% acquisition by a leading global energy company, according to the kingdom's crown prince.

title: Samsung's Lee Family to Offload Art as It Settles Tax Bill
summary: South Korea's wealthiest family faces massive inheritance taxes following the death of Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-hee last year.

title: GOP Leaders Clash on Trump at Annual Retreat
summary: Republicans hope to take back control of Congress in midterms. ORLANDO, Fla.-House GOP leaders presented clashing views at their annual gathering over the 2020 election, the best way to win back control of Congress and the role former President Donald Trump will play in the party's future.

title: Eric Schneiderman Loses Law License for One Year
summary: Former New York attorney general admits to engaging in professional misconduct and abusing previous girlfriends, disciplinary opinion says. A New York court on Tuesday barred former New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman from practicing law for a year, saying his admitted abuse of girlfriends was professional misconduct.

title: Pinterest CFO Looks to Ramp Up Spending on Marketing, Product Investments
summary: The image-sharing platform expects the number of U.S. users to plateau as the pandemic abates. Pinterest Inc.'s finance chief plans to spend more money on marketing to offset a potential slowdown in activity on its image-sharing platform as the U.S. economy reopens.
